184631: Glacial Chasm.author: Okuu-chan
184631: Glacial Chasm.text_parsed:
Sun Titan, Knight of the Reliquary

Sun Titan alleviates the Cumulative Upkeep by allowing you to sacrifice it without paying the cost and snaps it right back, stopping your opponent from hurting you. Knight of the Reliquary gets buffed off the sacrificed lands and will be able to attack. (It can also tutor for the chasm)

Neither an infinite combo nor a hard lock, but it can likely win games.

184632: Glacial Crevasses.author: Fabercastel
184632: Glacial Crevasses.text_parsed:
Is actually pretty decent tech for a mono red deck in Commander. This thing has saved my hide enough times to warrant a spot - it's not about setting up a perfect bubble against attacks, it's about making it less appealling for people to attack you instead of someone else.

Mono Red doesn't have many ways of playing the political game in the format and keeping themselves alive apart from Kazuul, Crawlspace or Ensnaring Bridge, and all of those aren't nearly as reliable. The latter two affect all the players and are magnets for removal; most people will leave this guy alone.

As someone mentioned, this should be played with Crucible of Worlds.

As someone mentioned, this should be played with Crucible of Worlds.

184633: Ice Floe.author: Mechanize
184633: Ice Floe.text_parsed:
I attack, opp Ice flows a creature, I relentless assault

Question 1: can I untap and attack again?

Question 2: What happens if I don't attack again and leave the creature untapped?

Question 3: If I do attack a 2nd time, does ice flow still prevent the creature from untapping on my next untap phase?
184633: Ice Floe.text_posted:
I attack, opp Ice flows a creature, I relentless assault

Question 1: can I untap and attack again? 

Question 2: What happens if I don't attack again and leave the creature untapped?  

Question 3: If I do attack a 2nd time, does ice flow still prevent the creature from untapping on my next untap phase?

184633: Ice Floe.author: igniteice
184633: Ice Floe.text_parsed:
@Mechanize

When you declare attacks, you simultaneously tap them. If your opponent responds to your attacker by tapping it with Ice Floe, it will already have been tapped and attacking. Ice Floe doesn't untap the creature to remove it from combat. He would need to use Ice Floe during the main phase or before attackers are declared. However, that said, your creature wouldn't untap during your untap phase if it became tapped again.

Here are some problems though with your scenario: Relentless Assault is a Sorcery. You can't cast it during combat. Sorceries may only (normally) be cast during main phases. Your opponent could however wait until after you cast Relentless Assault (until after it resolves), then during the Beginning of Combat phase (before Declare Attackers phase), he could use Ice Floes (if he hadn't already) and it would tap your creature before you could attack with it during the second combat phase.

184633: Ice Floe.author: Khardiss
184633: Ice Floe.text_parsed:
@leomistico - Incorrect. You cannot use Ice Floe to tap a creature. You use Ice Floe to prevent a creature that attacks you from untapping. If you use Tidewater Minion to untap your Ice Floe, then the creature you had trapped will be released and will untap during it's owners next untap phase. Also, Ice Floe does not stop the attack. When your opponent attacks you, you use Ice Floe to prevent his creature from untapping, but that attacking creature still attacks. You still need to block it or take the damage from it.

@igniteice - You do use Ice Floe during combat. It's ability states "Tap target creature without flying that is attacking you". How can you choose a target creature that's attacking you if attackers haven't been declared yet? When your opponent declares his attackers, you tap your Ice Floe to "trap" one of the attacking creatures, if that creature doesn't tap during attacks then you tap it. The creature does not untap until you choose to untap your Ice Floe (or some other spell/ability causes it to untap). It does not remove the attacking creature from combat, so any damage it would do would still occur.

@Mechanize - Question 1: Yes, you can untap and attack again. Ice Floe prevents your creature from untapping during your untap phase, it doesn't prevent you from untapping it using other spells or abilities. Question 2 & 3: The creature would remain untapped until the next time you tap it. If your opponent never untaps his Ice Floe, then your creature remains "attached" to it. If you use Relentless Assault to untap it, then wait X turns, then tap it to attack with, it would then remain tapped. If you never tap it again for the rest of the game (block only), then it would never get "trapped" again. If you do attack with it again, then it would become "trapped" again and would not untap during your normal untap phase.

184633: Ice Floe.author: leomistico
184633: Ice Floe.text_parsed:
You can also untap it with Tidewater Minion (or the like) to tap 2 creature during a single combat. With a single Ice Floe you can trap a couple of creatures... In this, Ice Floe can be better than Maze of Ith

5/5, sometimes it can be so annoying, but perfect for a control strategy, against an aggro. We need some more weapons to fight aggro/midrange!

Edit:
@leomistico - Incorrect. You cannot use Ice Floe to tap a creature. You use Ice Floe to prevent a creature that attacks you from untapping. If you use Tidewater Minion to untap your Ice Floe, then the creature you had trapped will be released and will untap during it's owners next untap phase. Also, Ice Floe does not stop the attack. When your opponent attacks you, you use Ice Floe to prevent his creature from untapping, but that attacking creature still attacks. You still need to block it or take the damage from it.

@Khardiss: you didn't understand a couple of things. Let's read the oracle text:
: Tap target creature without flying that's attacking you. It doesn't untap during its controller's untap step for as long as Ice Floe remains tapped.
Of course you can use it to tap a creature, it's written there! Sure the only revelant case is for a vigilant creature but so what? And I didn't say anything about use it to stop an attack, I know that Ice Floe doesn't stop it. And about untapping it: you have to tap Ice Floe, then in response of its ability untap it with the Minion and after that tap Ice Floe again before its first ability resolve. You have trapped 2 creatures, because the first creature doesn't see the Ice Floe that untapped, since it happened before the ability started to have effect...

Lightning Bolt
Dark Ritual
Healing Salve
Giant Growth
Ancestral Recall

True Ancestral Recall is way more powerful than the other cards, but in the beginning WotC didn't know that.

Incinerate just improves on a good staple, at the cost of 1 colorless. Worth it.

184638: Jester's Mask.author: TheSwarm
184638: Jester's Mask.text_parsed:
@ orson30..

Heres what I propose. Its a complicated setup, but you get argivian archaeologist, ornithopter, master transmuter, and amulet of vigor into play. do this, then get jesters mask into the grave. Then, tap two white, it hits your hand using argivian archaeologist, use master transmuter on the ornithopter, swap it for the mask, get it out untapped cuz of your amulet, then pay its cost, reuse. Next turn everything untaps and you can do the combo again. Kind of a complicated setup, but I think with certain artifacts and cards it can work... For instance, Cast insidious dreams, discarding the mask and some other cards to search up the rest of the combo.

184638: Jester's Mask.author: Mode
184638: Jester's Mask.text_parsed:
@nibelheim_valesti: Combining this with Goblin Welder actually seems like a fun casual combo.

The main problem with this card is that at the time you're going to activate the ability, your opponent won't have that many cards left in hand. So activating the ability early is an important part to profit from that.

Skill Borrower might also work with some luck.

Another good use for this might be with mass bounce effects.
Activate the ability, then put Evacuation on the stack, so you can exchange each creature (and any other card in his hand) for a land. Upheaval would be nice as well, but that one is a Sorcery...

@Sooku: Mindslaver would be the ultimate casual combo with this :D

184640: Johtull Wurm.author: Dr.Pingas
184640: Johtull Wurm.text_parsed:
I think people miss the idea of this guy COMPLETELY. He's a bulls-eye. You're meant to swing with him and an army of other green weenies and fatties and other bros, and they're going to see that downside of an ability and be torn over if they should block the creature who clearly becomes weaker, or if they should defend against other guys, potentially with "If this creature deals combat damage to a player" abilities.

Sure, not the absolute best plan, but people really have their heads up their butts when it comes to seeing how well a card can really function in spite of it's clear downsides.

184644: Kjeldoran Skycaptain.author: jfre81
184644: Kjeldoran Skycaptain.text_parsed:
Banding was absolutely sick on defense and, in its time, made a card like this worth paying five mana. You block as a band with something else, the attacking creature gets two first strike damage right off the bat, and then the defending player (not the attacking one) chooses how damage gets distributed - even trample damage.

Infect made me wish for the return of banding, or some retooled form of it that worked the same way on defense. You could block Blightsteel Colossus with a band and designate one of the creatures in the band as the recipient of all 11 infect damage. Beats the hell out of losing the game.

184647: Krovikan Vampire.author: jfre81
184647: Krovikan Vampire.text_parsed:
Before there was Captivating Vampire stealing your creatures, there was Krovikan Vampire.

His casting cost is not that high, considering his ability and the fact he's Dark Ritual-era black creature. Give him deathtouch with Basilisk Collar. Use Bullwhip to make something attack, and be blocked by this guy. With Bullwhip's 1 damage he can kill/steal any 4-toughness creature without any power boosts for Krovikan Vampire. Likewise, you can use effects that force a creature to block, and for this use it's better than Soul Collector as blocking the latter requires your target to have flying.

184648: Lava Burst.author: FoxdieUK
184648: Lava Burst.text_parsed:
Hi, New to Magic. Well actually used to play 15 odd years ago and recently got back into it after finding my cards in the loft.
This card is causing some arguments with my friend and me, basically, he's about to do 3 damage to my 1/1 creature. So i play, for example, giant growth on it. My argument is that im neither "preventing", or "re-directing" damage so the card should survive. His argument is that by playing Giant Growth i am playing an effect that is "preventing... damage.. to protect that creature".

Please help, game tonight and things get sour when this card hits the table.

Also, would Vines of Vastwood counter this card?
184648: Lava Burst.text_posted:
Hi, New to Magic. Well actually used to play 15 odd years ago and recently got back into it after finding my cards in the loft. 
This card is causing some arguments with my friend and me, basically, he's about to do 3 damage to my 1/1 creature. So i play, for example, [autocard]giant growth[/autocard] on it. My argument is that im neither "preventing", or "re-directing" damage so the card should survive. His argument is that by playing [autocard]Giant Growth[/autocard] i am playing an effect that is "preventing... damage.. to protect that creature".

Please help, game tonight and things get sour when this card hits the table.

Also, would [autocard]Vines of Vastwood[/autocard] counter this card?

184648: Lava Burst.author: lukemol
184648: Lava Burst.text_parsed:
Foxdie, your friend is wrong. You're still taking the same amount of damage, it is not preventing or redirecting the damage. It's just making your creature stronger so it doesn't die. Preventing would mean you somehow took less or none of the damage, redirecting would mean that you changed the target of the damage. You've done neither there.

Also, yes, Vines of Vastwood would in essence prevent it from happening (though not exactly the same as countering. The spell still resolves, it just does nothing). It sounds like your friend might not entirely understand the rules either. The last thing to be played is the first thing that resolves. So using the Giant Growth scenario, your friend plays Lightning Bolt which would deal 3 damage to your 1/1. You cast Giant Growth in response. The Giant Growth takes effect first, making your creature 4/4. Then his lightning bolt does 3 damage, which is not quite enough to take your guy out.

184648: Lava Burst.author: Salient
184648: Lava Burst.text_parsed:
Lava Burst was the first Fireball clone to suck.

No way, you say? Go look at the awesome array of damage prevention and redirection effects we had available in the Ice Age era. There was... Samite Healer! ...and... Healing Salve! (Note Lava Burst can't prevent you from using Healing Salve to just gain 3 life, and even Samite Healer could prevent 1 of the damage if the target was you rather than a creature.)

I think there were a couple other awful white creatures who prevented damage (that never even saw play in casual decks), but seriously, Lava Burst might as well have read "Effects which would plauphenate or transmorgify this damage can't take effect."

Still, "Overkill? This isn't a game of Kick-the-Ouphe!" is classic, and makes it all worthwhile. Sometimes I quote that when I manage to headshot a couple people in Counterstrike.

184652: Orcish Cannoneers.author: Gargantula
184652: Orcish Cannoneers.text_parsed:
So red has a long running subtheme of cards that can ping at the cost of dealing damage to you. At this point, there's enough of these "artillery" cards in the game to make a silly casual deck. I made that deck. Here it is:

4 basilisk collar
2 coldsteel heart
2 swiftfoot boots

2 deathless angel
4 goblin artillery
4 orcish artillery
3 orcish cannoneers
4 sparksmith
3 stuffy doll

4 pariah
3 personal sanctuary
2 enlightened tutor
1 orcish cannonade

2 vault of the archangel
(more land)

So personal sanctuary and artillery cards certainly have nice synergy as personal sanctuary removes the downside of artillery as long as you use it on your turn. Pariah is great too. Pariah is a fantastic card by itself. But it works well with artillery- if you need to kill a fairly big creature badly, you can now tap an artillery and 5 damage will hit the creature: the three damage that artillery would do to you is rerouted to the creature with pariah on it. Add that to the 2 dmg you've dealt to the creature already with an artillery. Or if you like, take out two separate smaller creatures. What's nice is that you can still do pariah artillery antics while personal sanctuary is in play- you just do them during the opponent's turn.

The fun starts when you stick pariah on a stuffy doll. By itself, I think pariah plus stuffy doll is a sort of mean and predictable combo and I'm not crazy about it. But what is fun is when you have that combo out and artiillery cards on the battlefield. Congratulations, you've now turned your artillery into a 5 dmg per turn threat! Or deal two dmg to an opponent's creature, three damage to them, and repeat it the next turn. And you're probably not going to die so long as they can't get rid of stuffy plus pariah...

And then there's basilisk collar. An artillery equipped with basilisk collar destroys a creature and the lifelink negates the damage the artillery deals to you, so you actually gain 2 life every time you use the equipped artillery. The funny thing is that if absolutely everything goes right in the deck, a basilisk collared artillery can do 5 damage to an opponent and gain you 5 life every turn. See how?

I also "splash" black with city of brass and vivid crag/meadow for vault of the archangel. Worth it? Idk.

So the deck isn't particularly good, but it is ironic- it turns the downside of a fairly bad line of cards into an advantage. And if you have some casual Johnny in your blood, that's something that you can't help but enjoy.

P.S.- Mogg maniac certainly wouldn't be bad in the deck either, as he has synergy with pariah and sparksmith. Also pain land+ pariah= fun

184656: Orcish Lumberjack.author: Mode
184656: Orcish Lumberjack.text_parsed:
Decent mana accel, three additional mana at the cost of a land on a 1/1 one-drop is great!
It's generally a whole lot better than Goblin Clearcutter since this is most important in the early game.
If it's in your opening hand you might play a mid-game spell for five mana for on turn two for instance, or two 3/3 Coal Stokers and another spell for three mana, which might bring you more forward despite the fact that you'll have one less mana on the subsequent turns.

This Orc is also hundred times better than Mana Seism most of the time: The Seism would require saccing 6 lands to get more mana than the Lumberjack. That means unless you can certainly win by saccing 5 more lands, this seriously isn't a good idea.
If you are looking for a related card in a deck, i advise using Squandered Resources.

184656: Orcish Lumberjack.author: Nate_Prawdzik
184656: Orcish Lumberjack.text_parsed:
This guy was a "kill me or lose" card when he came down on turn 1. The time frame for this was back when Erhnam Djinn was the best 4 drop around (and one of the best creatures in general). Not only did you get rid of forests that the opponent might forest-walk on, but the turn after Erhnam hit, you could either slap down a crippling Winter Orb (and still have this guy ready to let you cheat the Orb), or you could simply tap a Forest and a white source (like Birds of Paradise) for Armageddon (which kind of invalidates drawbacks to both this card and to Erhnam).

The other terrifying early play was this guy on turn 1, Tinder Wall on turn 2 = turn 2 Shivan Dragon.

This was a really, really crazy card in it's day. Note that mana denial strategies let you have a chance against the dominant Necropotence decks of the day, whose pro-white knights you could Lightning Bolt, Hypnotic Specters you could Swords to Plowshares, and whose pumping or drain life spells were crippled by 'geddon/orb. Erhnam and Burn 'Em / Erhna-Geddon (or hybrid) was the name of the game for green decks, and Orcish Lumberjack was the Turn 1 All-Star.

I love that MTG slang goes far beyond regional dialect. "Pump Knight". So glad to see that here. Good card. A trhow back to the day where color hosing was king. While not as first-strikey as it's predacessor, White Knight, the option to pump the knight would be too good IMO if 1st strike was not an activated ability. Having to pay for 1st strike is far outdone by the option to pump. Excellent card. So nice they printed it twice (more if you could alt art).
3.5/5

I understand why someone thought it was a good idea to give Stone Spirit, Wind Spirit, Flame Spirit, and Sea Spirit the Elemental creature type. I even think it's kinda cool. But the fact is, not one of these cards has ever been printed as anything but a plain ol' Spirit.

As much as possible, Oracle should reflect what's printed on the cards. This is just muddying the waters.

And he put the deck into pink sleeves. The name? "Two in the Pink". Genius.

184661: Portent.author: blurrymadness
184661: Portent.text_parsed:
Being able to control someone's draws is a brutal bit of tech. I've always wanted to use this, Misinformation and cards that mill just one card at time to build a deck where you constantly control their draws into continually more useless stuff.

Between counterspells and kill spells you can hold the early game while stuff like this tries to ensure there is never a late game. Sounds both obnoxious and fun to me!

184664: Ritual of Subdual.author: kiseki
184664: Ritual of Subdual.text_parsed: An artifact deck with green splash, everflowing chalice, and two proliferate/energy chamber effects could keep this up indefinitely. The benefit over Eon Hub is that the Chalice/Proliferate/Energy Chambers are already amazing by themselves, so you aren't playing cards that are useless outside of a combo in the deck. Add in a few arcbound creatures to ensure you are developing your board in the meantime. My deck also has Prototype Portal, artifact lands, and the urzatron so the lock is pretty easy to maintain if they miss the window.

184664: Ritual of Subdual.author: Guest1162619373
184664: Ritual of Subdual.text_parsed:
You don't need Eon Hub with this. Fast mana accel with a Mana Flare and artifact mana. If you run instant burn, you can burn them using Volcanic Geyser at the beginning of your upkeep with the Ritual of Subdual still in play. Even with the amount of artifact mana available, many players still don't use them meaning you can lock them out of being able to cast anything early in the game, and with the Mana Flares keep the Ritual of Subdual in play for an extended amount of time while using red sweepers to kill their creatures and shatters/naturalizes to kill artifact mana producers. The deck does work as I built the deck a long time ago running Fire Diamonds and Moss Diamonds with sweepers. The only decks that gave me problems were decks that had pro-Red creatures, counter decks, and fast aggro decks that killed me before I could drop a Glacial Chasm. I won one game against a white deck that was holding Eye for an Eye that couldn't be cast because I cast Volcanic Geyser for lethal in response to the upkeep trigger of the Ritual.

A current build is G/W with Cloudposts, Glimmerposts, and Vesuva's + artifact mana for a mana base. It's pretty effective, for the most part. Still looking to throw it into a FFA sometime for giggles.

The spell costs what it costs because it can lock an opponent down hard.

@boneclub: I simply stated it wasn't necessary, and it actually isn't necessarily easier to run an Eon Hub, either. Especially when you consider it's harder to play after the Ritual is in play, is about as slow to play as the Ritual (about the time you can cast the Eon Hub you either want to be playing the Ritual itself or wiping the board) and is trumped by a 2 casting cost artifact the Power Conduit which can be played on turn 2 or after the Ritual has been in play for a turn or two easily. If all you're interested in is dealing with the upkeep for the Ritual there are much better options than the Eon Hub. It is a good card in it's own right; however, the deck needs to be built to take advantage of it instead of put into a deck where another card is more effective.

The deck does work as I built the deck a long time ago running Fire Diamonds and Moss Diamonds with sweepers.  The only decks that gave me problems were decks that had pro-Red creatures, counter decks, and fast aggro decks that killed me before I could drop a Glacial Chasm.  I won one game against a white deck that was holding Eye for an Eye that couldn't be cast because I cast Volcanic Geyser for lethal in response to the upkeep trigger of the Ritual.

A current build is G/W with Cloudposts, Glimmerposts, and Vesuva's + artifact mana for a mana base.  It's pretty effective, for the most part.  Still looking to throw it into a FFA sometime for giggles.

The spell costs what it costs because it can lock an opponent down hard.

@boneclub:  I simply stated it wasn't necessary, and it actually isn't necessarily easier to run an Eon Hub, either.  Especially when you consider it's harder to play after the Ritual is in play, is about as slow to play as the Ritual (about the time you can cast the Eon Hub you either want to be playing the Ritual itself or wiping the board) and is trumped by a 2 casting cost artifact the [autocard]Power Conduit[/autocard] which can be played on turn 2 or after the Ritual has been in play for a turn or two easily.  If all you're interested in is dealing with the upkeep for the Ritual there are much better options than the Eon Hub.  It is a good card in it's own right; however, the deck needs to be built to take advantage of it instead of put into a deck where another card is more effective.

184670: Stampede.author: kiseki
184670: Stampede.text_parsed:
This is the ONLY instant that gives trample to all of your creatures. And let me tell you, instant speed trample can be backbreaking.
Overrun is overkill. This allows you to sneak a subtler victory. Overrun is blocked correctly, this probably isn't. This is also much easier to use in decks that would struggle with reliably getting .
Now you have a use for the large efficient green creatures that don't have trample. Here are some green fatties that love surprise trample:
Nacatl War-Pride!!! (all the tokens get trample! take that overrun!)
Engulfing Slagwurm (otherwise it wouldn't be blocked)
Cloudthresher (high utility creature that isn't suspicious without trample)

184673: Stromgald Cabal.author: Justice1337
184673: Stromgald Cabal.text_parsed:
With Eight-and-a-Half Tails, awesome, sure, but one thing that hasn't been mentioned is the particular types of spells that one would typically want to counter, and whether they are white by themselves. Most obvious are sweeper spells, like Wrath of God and Planar Cleansing, though of course, some exist in every color. To a lesser extent life gain is most often white, and the most annoying cards of that theme certianly are, like Beacon of Immortality and Felidar Sovereign. But most importantly, exile removal is white, like Swords to Plowshares and Path to Exile. Throw out this kind of removal, and regeneration starts to become very attractive. Most creature based decks don't like sweepers and life-gain, and a lot of black creature decks have some sort of regeneration. Whether you actually activate this or not, that kind of deck could sometimes afford to run a 3 mana 2/2 with no abilities in a context where they are guaranteed not to see sweepers and exile removal.

Given this, it's not unheard of that a deck would play this main-deck, especially if is running a Knights subtheme. Also, this is going to be very good in multiplayer a lot of the time. I give it 4.5/5 for being insane against one color, and still not bad blind, unlike the Paladins.

184675: Swords to Plowshares.author: Bauble
184675: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed:
Path To Exile being better than this is arguable. I honestly prefer path to swords because you'd usually use path on some uber creature (like, say Darksteel Colossus) that you couldn't merely Cancel or Essence Scatter because they got him out via Master Transmuter, Elvish Piper, Mayael The Anima and so many more. If you Swords of Plowshares Darksteel, your opponent gains 11 life, by which, under normal circumstances, you'd usually swear and sometimes concede. Path To Exile merely gives them 1 basic land, which, under normal circumstances, you'd just sigh and continue. I've even played a game against a mate in which he had no basic lands to search for. So really, it's a gamble, but you don't really lose much. Your opponent gains a basic land. It's still tapped, so it isn't worse than if your opponent played Harrow.

Swords To Plowshares is still really good, and although better is subjective, Path To Exile has my vote.

184675: Swords to Plowshares.author: Temple_Garden
184675: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed:
In most situations I'd rather give my opponents life from Swords than the land from Path to Exile but there are many situations where Path to Exile will be a superior card. At the end of the day most decks win by getting their opponents to 0 life. Sometimes you will win by scraping through that last 1 or 2 damage, in a situation like that you would probably not want to play this card over Path to Exile, particularly if you can win before they even get to use the land they tutored from the Path to Exile.

This card delays your opponents death (which will almost always matter), Path to Exile accelerates your opponent's win (which only matters if you can't win first). Depending on your strategy, deck and their deck, either card could be better at that time.

At the end of the day most decks win by getting their opponents to 0 life. Sometimes you will win by scraping through that last 1 or 2 damage, in a situation like that you would probably not want to play this card over Path to Exile, particularly if you can win before they even get to use the land they tutored from the Path to Exile.

This card delays your opponents death (which will almost always matter), Path to Exile accelerates your opponent's win (which only matters if you can't win first). Depending on your strategy, deck and their deck, either card could be better at that time.

184675: Swords to Plowshares.author: Diachronos
184675: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed:
The problem with Path is that you're letting your opponent get their expensive cards out faster. And what if the creature you just Pathed was the only one they've been able to play because they don't have the proper color or number of lands to play other cards?

Granted, Path can be good if it's late enough in the game that it won't make much of a difference (or if they use few, if any, basic lands; one of my friends has a 5-color with only non-basic lands), but I'd much rather give them life than give them land otherwise.

How many ways can you get rid of life? Too many to count.
How many ways can you get rid of land? Very few, and they're practically non-existent outside of {R}.

184675: Swords to Plowshares.author: BongRipper420
184675: Swords to Plowshares.text_parsed:
Swords to Plowshares vs Path To Exile: The pros and cons of each.

Swords to plowshares shines in the early game. This is because it's targets will usually be utility creatures with small power, like Birds of Paradise, Delver of Secrets, Goblin Lackey, Noble Hiearch, Priest of Titania, Hypnotic Specter, ect. It's often very worth it to give an opponent 1 or 2 life to get rid of powerful utility creatures. So StP is quite powerful during the early game for that reason.

Later in the game, however when your opponent begins playing late game creatures which have a larger power, you'll be giving an opponent not just 1-2 life, but 8+. And while life can always be damaged, giving them too much life can easily give them too much time to kill you. That can be bad.

Path to Exile on the other hand, plays very differently. If you use PtE on an early game utility creature, you're giving your opponent a land, and putting them one turn ahead of you when it matters. So if you path or opponent's turn 1 creature, they'll likely have at least 3 lands available on their turn 2, which could be the death of you rather easily. Not to mention your thinning their deck of land draws.

That being said, later in the game when both players have plenty of land out already, giving your opponent an additional land will have minimal impact on the game. Which is why Path to Exileis usually better in the late game.

So in conclusion, both cards are really, really good.

184676: Thermokarst.author: ninjabear
184676: Thermokarst.text_parsed:
In the beginning, there was Stone Rain, Ice Storm and Sinkhole, and all was good.
Then, Revised came and the Powers that Be decided that Red would be the Land Destruction color, and thus, wiped out of existence the green and black land destruction cards. (Well, not really. somehow Desert Twister got into Revised from Arabian).
But in Ice Age, the Powers that Be became a bit more benevolent towards Land Destruction, and they returned that ability to the former colors, but in a less powerful variant: Thermokarst and Icequake. And all was good again.
And thus, a tradition of black and green land destruction began. Cards like Choking Sands, Rancid Earth, Mwonvuli Acid-Moss, Drain the Well, Winter's Grasp, Rain of Tears, Plow Under, Creeping Mold ...

Considering White has Armageddon, only blue doesn't have a way to get rid of nasty lands. Well, actually they do... Strip Mine,Wasteland,Ghost Quarter, Dust Bowl and so many others... and nasty things like Temporal Eddy or Boomerang.

Question regarding damage order ruling.. If you detonate the TIme Bomb for enough damage to kill all creatures, and both players, does the damage occur simultaneously to creatures and players? More specifically, if you had an Ali from Cairo in play, would his ability save you from dying, even though the Ali will die.

If that isn't enough, is it possible to manipulate Fortune Thief to prevent lethal damage? For instance, does paying the morph cost count as an activated instant in response to the damage being dealt against the facedown 2/2?

I realize that this could all be sidestepped just by using a Glacial Chasm or something, but it's just so much more fun trying to manipulate the battlefield this way.

T1: Mountain, Orcish Lumberjack
T2: Forest, tinder wall.

Tap mountain, sac tinder wall, 3 red mana. Cut down forest with Lumberjack, BAM! 6 mana, 3 red, 3 green. 4 cards, too, allowing for 3 card combos, as long as they're cheap.

You could go with a Bloodbraid Elf, cascade into something else, and still have enough for TWO lightning bolts! thats at least 9 damage, turn three. Even more if you cascade into a Titanic Growth, or Be able to replay the combo, with an Eternal Witness!

6 mana turn two is a DANGEROUS thing to contend with, simply put. such a big bang like this early on will END games fast, IF you manage to protect yourself correctly. if you lose your advantage from this, you'll be basically screwed.

-x-

@Charles_Prefect: my mistake. Edited it for my new review of the card. x3

184681: Withering Wisps.author: blurrymadness
184681: Withering Wisps.text_parsed:
While this is quite good, Pestilence is better *some* of the time; noteably anytime you ramp via rituals, coffers, or some other situations that ramp incredible amounts of black mana into your pool.

Because of this, this card can only ever be used with ramping in an opponent's turn (pay most of your swamps in yours, leave some open for instant speed ramping in the opponent's to get more out of the enchant.)

Pesti is much easier to use and also.. much less annoying to keep track of. Still a good 3.5/5 or 4/5 card given the power, but it's much less abusable.

184681: Withering Wisps.author: The_Murderauder
184681: Withering Wisps.text_parsed:
Interesting to note that the oracle wording has changed this card's functionality somewhat. Whereas previously it referred to a specific card by name (Snow-Covered Swamp), it now works off of any card that has both the Snow Supertype and the Swamp subtype. If you turned your Scrying Sheets into a swamp with Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth, for example, or put an ice counter on an existing Swamp with Rimefeather Owl, and either of those lands would now count towards your "snow Swamp" count.

Will this make a difference in any future game of Magic that will ever be played? My money's on no, probably not.

Also note that you CAN use black mana from any source whatsoever to pay for the ability, you just can't activate it more times than you have snow Swamps. Usually these two are the same thing, but not always. You could, theoretically, tap all your snow Swamps for damage on your turn, then on your opponent's turn use your Cabal Coffers/Dark Ritual/Whatever to pay for the ability again. The same "number of snow Swamps" clause applies, of course.

Will THIS make a difference? Yeah, probably.

184681: Withering Wisps.author: KFrosty
184681: Withering Wisps.text_parsed:
@Overfiend Surprise and other naysayers of this. Cabal Coffers and this DO combo, but not within the same turn.

Example, with three swamps, you can do this:
Your turn:
use Cabal Coffers and hit for 3 damage.

Enemy Turn:
Use Dark Ritual, and hit for 3 damage.

With more than 3 swamps, you can do this:
Your turn:
use Cabal coffers and hit for X damage.

Enemy Turn:
Tap the rest of your lands for the rest of the damage.

It is still the same damage output from Pestilence, but the key difference is that this is one mana cheaper, while Pesti can do it all on the same turn.

184685: Brassclaw Orcs.author: Gandlodder
184685: Brassclaw Orcs.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune
There were no dwarves in Zendikar, but Shadowmoor had a few. Misshapen, derpy, and mostly harmless, but still dwarves.

The last useful dwarves were printed in Odyssey block, with stuff like Dwarven Bloodboiler and Dwarven Recruiter.
The last orcs were printed in Tenth Edition (Orcish Artillery) and Time Spiral before that, as throwbacks.

The obvious reason for the diminishing of the Orcs and Dwarves is the rampant popularity of the Goblins as THE red tribe. One ray of hope has appeared with the tribal Minotaurs present in Theros, although they probably exist only becuase Goblins wouldn't make much sense for the setting (although, Kamigawa...)

The problem is, that two creatures are blocking a creature I control, but one is a Stinkweed Imp (in effect Deathtouch), whose 1 damage alone, due to its special power, will kill my creature. This is the damage I want to prevent, not the damage from the other attacker, who can't kill my creature anyway.

184690: Goblin Ski Patrol.author: Aquillion
184690: Goblin Ski Patrol.text_parsed:
@TPmanW: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.

If you use it with Sundial of the Infinite, here's what happens:

It does stay 3/1 flying permanently.
However, by the Oracle Text wording, you still have to sacrifice it at the start of the next end step. Using the Sundial to completely skip your end phase for a turn doesn't let you escape this; it only delays it until the next turn, since it means that that next turn's end step is the "next end step."

Actually, thinking about it, I think you could possibly wait until the start of your next end step, when the sacrifice-this-creature ability goes on the stack, then in response activate Sundial of the Infinite to end the turn; the Sundial resolves first and ends the turn, causing everything on the stack to be discarded, and since you did have your "next end step" it won't activate it again.

Regardless, you cannot activate it a second time to make it 5/1, no matter what. Its ability, as the Oracle ruling says, can only be activated once per game, period. Not once per turn. You could reset that by flickering it (which makes it lose its history), but this also resets its power to 1.
184690: Goblin Ski Patrol.text_posted:
@TPmanW:  Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.

If you use it with Sundial of the Infinite, here's what happens:

However, by the Oracle Text wording, you still have to sacrifice it at the start of the next end step.  Using the Sundial to completely skip your end phase for a turn doesn't let you escape this; it only delays it until the next turn, since it means that that next turn's end step is the "next end step."

Actually, thinking about it, I think you could possibly wait until the start of your next end step, when the sacrifice-this-creature ability goes on the stack, then in response activate Sundial of the Infinite to end the turn; the Sundial resolves first and ends the turn, causing everything on the stack to be discarded, and since you did have your "next end step" it won't activate it again.

Regardless, you cannot activate it a second time to make it 5/1, no matter what.  Its ability, as the Oracle ruling says, can only be activated once [i]per game[/i], period.  Not once per turn.    You could reset that by flickering it (which makes it lose its history), but this also resets its power to 1.

It's a real gem of a griefer card.

184698: Misinformation.author: SAUS3
184698: Misinformation.text_parsed:
So funny. I really want to use this against some derpy blue mage with a top keeping their counterspell on top of their deck.

Basically, I cast something they don't like and they're like 'I have a response... Activate top' - Welp I have a response too bro! *Cast this*. They draw a land and my spell resolves.

It would be glorious.

But yes. Even with that scenario aside, this can reeaally mess with your opponent. Notice they're a little mana screwed? Throw some of those non-lands back on top of their deck. Notice they have ineffective cards in their graveyard (like a raging goblin in the late game), let them draw into that.

5/5 but I see why this kind of effect has not really been reprinted. It would be hella annoying.

184700: Night Soil.author: sonorhC
184700: Night Soil.text_parsed:
This card has won me so many games with my token deck. The best was one time I was in a four-player game, and one of the other players cast an Inferno. His plan was to use Resurrection on his Shivan Dragon the next turn, so he'd have a nice empty field to dominate. He didn't notice I already had Night Soil out :> I ended up with the nice empty field instead, with about a dozen tokens to take advantage of it.

On another note, does anyone else think this should have been reprinted in Ravnica block? It's a perfect match for the Golgari.

184708: Phantasmal Mount.author: longwinded
184708: Phantasmal Mount.text_parsed:
This card is an interesting collision of flavor-based mechanics that get in the way of what the card really wants to do. First, it wants to carry a rider by giving it +1/+1 and flying. This sort of "mount/guard duty" mechanic is used on earlier cards like Wyluli Wolf and contemporaries like Kjeldoran Guard. Unfortunately, it can only carry a rider so large -- much like the Dwarven Warriors can only convey a creature of a certain size through their tunnels -- so power must be 2 or less. And, like some other guards, it uses basically the same mechanic that the proto-equipment -- such as Sandals of Abdallah, Flying Carpet, Tawnos's Weaponry and Runesword -- in that it is lost on the field/goes down with its user.

Rich with flavor. Choking on flavor. And that's eventually what lead them to favor simplicity over flavor. Chasm Drake is a newer card that goes for similar effects (minus the headaches), and Avacyn Restored's upcoming Soulbond mechanic offers something sort of similar with Wingcrafter. Personally, I wish they had done true equipment (using attachment the way auras do) earlier. Maybe then they would have made the leap to creatures that attach to other creatures, which seems like a cleaner way to do some of the things they've tried in the past.

184710: Spore Cloud.author: DeadLeeCoC
184710: Spore Cloud.text_parsed:
I'll never understand why this is rated so low. Its debatable whether they would even consider printing it today. Printing a fog card like this or tangle would be a little dangerous to modern. Its not just a stall card, its also a very potent (but circumstantial) overrun enabler.

Imagine a 4th or 5th turn pivot with this card. You're playing something green and stompy with your choice of well costed beaters they've been printing these days.. (I'm looking at you tarmogoyf)

So, Your opponent swings 4th turn. ...you don't block, you just cast Spore cloud. Now, you get to punish them for your next two turns while those creatures are locked down. If they're still alive come 6th turn, you've failed as a magic player.

184713: Karplusan Giant.author: longwinded
184713: Karplusan Giant.text_parsed:
I kind of feel bad for this card. There was just no technology or experience at the time to make it good. The way creatures were priced back then was fairly linear with respect ot power/toughness, whereas today things ramp up in power considerably after 4 CMC to make creatures comparable to spells in power.

So if you're a developer in these times of CMC = ~max(P, T). This set will also introduce the largest creature ever, an 11/11 with CMC 11 (with a considerable drawback). You're working on a card with the theme "snow lands make it stronger -- tap one to give it +1/+1". Which means, effectively, that it's CMC is X, and once it attacks its P/T could be P+X+1/T+X+1. Now, find a fair X.

You can't. If you start of with a Hill Giant at 3/3 for CMC 4, you're basically dedicating to have an 8/8 swinging around turn 5. Sooner with moxen, Dark Rituals, and lotuses, though those will of course make it weaker. The fair thing to do is reduce the gap by reducing the printed P/T, like they did with Mountain Titan... which puts it at about 1/1, and as soon as you tap out any Zuran Spellcaster can kill it. Lame.

So now you've figure out linear pricing + drawbacks don't work well. Maybe you could reduce the CMC by making it double-, or even triple-red? (If it only fits in mono-red decks, why not just give it {R}: +1/+1?) Or gold? (We have plenty of gold cards. Make this work as a mediocre-range red card.) So there goes all previous experience to draw on. Not that it's a lot. This is only the 6th expansion, the first large expansion. What do you do?

Well, from a practical standpoint a 10/10 and a 12/12 aren't very different from one another.... Boom, CMC 7. Maybe someone will figure out how to cast it. After all, moxen, rituals, lotuses, etc. Yeah, this guy has a shot. And "sucks for defense" is a drawback after all, even if it's not spelled out. It's like a big Ironclaw Orcs. That effectively sucks mana. Right?

(Nevermind that the first Sligh deck won't even be invented until after this set and the two sets after this is released. Yes, this card predates both the notions mana curve and of "drawbacks don't matter" aggro by two sets. As I said, this guy never had a shot.)
184713: Karplusan Giant.text_posted:
I kind of feel bad for this card. There was just no technology or experience at the time to make it good. The way creatures were priced back then was fairly linear with respect ot power/toughness, whereas today things ramp up in power considerably after 4 CMC to make creatures comparable to spells in power.

So if you're a developer in these times of CMC = ~max(P, T). This set will also introduce the largest creature ever, an 11/11 with CMC 11 (with a considerable drawback). You're working on a card with the theme "snow lands make it stronger -- tap one to give it +1/+1". Which means, effectively, that it's CMC is X, and once it attacks its P/T could be P+X+1/T+X+1.  Now, find a fair X.

184716: Imperial Recruiter.author: majinara
184716: Imperial Recruiter.text_parsed:
It's expensive for several reasons: First small print run. Especially the english version of this set had a really tiny print run and were only released in Australia and New Zealand. Then he wasn't in the starter packs, which also would have reduced his value.
The important thing though is: it's a tutor. And a very flexible one. It can fetch everything from Dark Confidant to Solemn Simulacrum to Birds of Paradise to Weathered Wayfarer or whatever.
Also, it's not only a tutor: it's a tutor on a creature. Which means if you reanimate him, bounce him and replay him, flicker him or whatever: you can keep tutoring for cards. He can also attack and block. All in all an awesome (albeit not overpowered) card. I have it on MTGO and play it there in my EDH/Commander decks.

Tiny print run + high value for collectors + highly playable card = expensive.

184716: Imperial Recruiter.author: JARYISM
184716: Imperial Recruiter.text_parsed:
His ability was one of those overlooked flukes from Three Kingdoms that I guess Wizards just allowed to go through in the other formats...

In faster formats like Legacy, he's had some success in Aluren and Painter but he's an absolute BEAST in EDH. This is a sample of what he can get for you depending on the situation:

Solemn
Oracle of Mul-Daya
Kiki-Jiki
Siege-Gang
Duplicant
Acidic Slime
ANY Clone
Eternal Witness
Spike Weaver
Seadborn Muse
Mulldrifter
Mentor of the Meek
Trinket Mage
Stone Forge Mystic
...And that's just a small sample. He's also easily abused with Genesis/Skullclamp, and like someone said Flickerwisp/Ghostaway affects. I've found that he's best used to setup for those kinda plays where you can creative massove CA, sort of like an Astral Slide abuse.

184717: Imperial Seal.author: scumbling1
184717: Imperial Seal.text_parsed:
I can't believe they released this card in Master's Edition! This is one of the most obscure cards in all of Magic, but Wizards was willing to make it available to the those on the internet. Even if you're willing to drop the serious cash on a physical copy of this card, it's still difficult to find a vendor with one to sell.


@ wgillespie: It's simply supply and demand. Portal: Three Kingdoms was printed in very small quantities, and primarily for Asian markets. The English versions of the cards were (I believe) only released in New Zealand and Australia. This leads to anything being remotely playable from the set reaching sky-high prices.

Imperial Seal is much better than "remotely playable". It costs you two life, which is completely irrelevant. What is important is that it's one black mana to get anything you want. Notice how Vampiric Tutor and Demonic Tutor end up on banned / restricted lists, while Diabolic Tutor doesn't even see the slightest play; paying life is a much preferrable alternative to paying mana. Notice how cards such as Channel and Necropotence also need regulation. You start the game at twenty life, but you don't necessarily start with any mana.

Even if you're willing to drop the serious cash on a physical copy of this card, it's still difficult to find a vendor with one to sell. 


@ wgillespie: It's simply supply and demand. Portal: Three Kingdoms was printed in very small quantities, and primarily for Asian markets. The English versions of the cards were (I believe) only released in New Zealand and Australia. This leads to anything being remotely playable from the set reaching sky-high prices. 

Imperial Seal is much better than "remotely playable". It costs you two life, which is completely irrelevant. What is important is that it's one black mana to get anything you want. Notice how Vampiric Tutor and Demonic Tutor end up on banned / restricted lists, while Diabolic Tutor doesn't even see the slightest play; paying life is a much preferrable alternative to paying mana. Notice how cards such as Channel and Necropotence also need regulation. You start the game at twenty life, but you don't necessarily start with any mana.

184718: Essence Filter.author: Knightaru
184718: Essence Filter.text_parsed:
All you guys talking about Enchanted Evening combos are forgetting that EE makes all White permanents into White Enchantments. So you simply splash Green in your White Enchanted Evening deck, and this suddenly becomes a one-sided board wipe, with the (comparatively) minor side-effect that you also blow up your Lands in the process. Oh, and since Enchanted Evening itself is White, all your remaining permanents are still Enchantments . . . you know, just in case you're using Ethereal Armor or something . . .

Of course, if you're facing an opposing White deck, you can simply O-Ring your own stuff (or, better yet, have your opponent O-Ring your stuff) and simply use EE->EF to blow up everything indiscriminately, maintaining board advantage in the aftermath. (Be careful setting up Enchanted Evening if said opposing White player is packing significant Enchantment hate of their own, though.)

The problem here i think it that this card tries to be two things at once and fails at both.
(Consider many cards i'm going to list did not exist in Ice Age)

The idea was to have a creature that can take any colors to take advantage of other cards' effects that make use of it (Bloom Tender for example), which were possibly more used in multicolored decks (therefore it only costs a single blue mana). 184722: Aether Storm.author: exterion
184722: Aether Storm.text_parsed:
Note that it's worded 'destroy' in the oracle text, meaning indestructibility would work too. The problem is, your opponent can just pay 4 life to destroy it in response to inestructibilty/faith's fetters/whatever. Trickbind solves this problem, Interdict doesn't (if your opponent is willing to pay more life).

@littlebeast: While I don't think there's anything that says "Regenerate target enchantment", it's possible to regenerate it as a creature if Opalescense is in play.
The reason they used that term is because bury was changed into either 'sacrifice' or 'destroy, it can't be regenerated'. Since your opponents can't sacrifice permanents you control, the destroy wording was decided to be simpler for this card.

184722: Aether Storm.author: Ragamander
184722: Aether Storm.text_parsed:
@Dr.Pingas: Aether Storm cannot be regenerated when its ability resolves. Boros Charm and Indestructibility would work, though. Pithing Needle is cheaper, though, and you can drop it prior to Aether Storm (making it impossible for them to respond by activating Aether Storm's ability). Of course, getting past a Boros Charm would take an extra four life...which is so much better than just burning them directly for four.

Mindslaver and Sorin Markov also seem potentially brutal here. Forcing it through is complicated, though. You need a Pithing Needle or a Trickbind into Indestructibility, but if you go with the Needle you would need to get rid of it before taking your opponent's turn. Or you could use Sundial of the Infinite, ending the turn if they try to blow it up in response to Indestructibility. You lose the Indestructibility, but you made them take another four. And, well, I guess that's something.

You could also Copy Enchantment until they don't have enough life to get through all of them. Then cast Aether Tradewinds whenever they try to blow one up.

184724: Ravages of War.author: DarthParallax
184724: Ravages of War.text_parsed:
I think this is a very well designed sleek card and the only thing holding it back is its mana cost. I get that it's inappropriate for the game as is, but if you make it cost 6 or more you can have it be possible to build a deck that has the POTENTIAL to do kinda-this in Standard, but it will be difficult enough to make work that it won't be a dominant or oppressive force on the format. Take a look at Temporal Mastery's current impact on Standard:

Hey! Look! The World didn't End!

So obviously very very powerful cards can get made and not ruin MAGIC. I say they should try to make another card that says "Destroy All Lands" and see how that works out for them! :)

184726: Armor of Faith.author: longwinded
184726: Armor of Faith.text_parsed:
@mrredhatter
Actually, this card is a compromise between Holy Strength which gives a better P/T bonus but no pumping, and Blessing which gives pumping but no inherent P/T bonuses. Since the CC is less than Blessing, gives a built-in +1/+1 and the ability to do a defensive "half-pump," I'd say it fits in pretty well.

edit: Oh, and I forgot to mention it's an ever-so-slight variation on the earlier Holy Armor.

Sorry Frag. The new combat rules mean creatures all have "Creature-Trample". Their damage spills over onto each blocker till its all assigned.
Old rules meant that the 1/1 could take the hit, and others in the band would be ok.

However if you're refering to instant blockers, you can get 2 soldiers for the same price.

184730: Errand of Duty.author: Wraique
184730: Errand of Duty.text_parsed:
Negative psyklone. The old rule still applies to banding. You get to assign your opponent's creature's combat damage any which way you want when it's coming at a band, meaning the 1/1 could take it all.

702.19k During the combat damage step, if a blocking creature is blocking a creature with banding,
or both a creature with ‚Äúbands with other ‚Äù and another creature, the
active player (rather than the defending player) chooses how the blocking creature‚Äôs damage is
assigned. That player can divide that creature‚Äôs combat damage as he or she chooses among any
number of creatures it‚Äôs blocking. This is an exception to the procedure described in rule 510.1d.

184733: Iceberg.author: yyukichigai
184733: Iceberg.text_parsed:
Not quite as useful as a Gemstone Array overall, but if you need something to float some absurd amount of mana you received during your main phase and you have this in hand then this is your best bet. Once you get it on the board it's not strictly bad for storing mana either; if nothing else you can put whatever leftover mana you have into it at the end of the turn. Still, for that you're better off with the Gemstone Array.

Also has a weird potential interaction with Dark Depths, which uses the same counters. Animate it with something like Wind Zendikon and you could use Fate Transfer to snag 10 colorless mana and a 20/20 Flying Indestructible Avatar at the same time. Hell of a combo to pull off though.

184734: Drift of the Dead.author: yyukichigai
184734: Drift of the Dead.text_parsed:
@metalviolence: During the initial Ice Age block you could run as many basic snow-covered lands as you wanted. Since they did and still do qualify as basic lands there was no limit to the number of them you could have in one deck. That's why this card saw some play, seeing as it could come out late-game as a large enough blocker to stop whatever beast your opponent was trying to do you in with.

Anyway, it's not bad exactly, but it's only useful in Snow decks and even then the cost is probably 1CMC too high. It's also a bit out-of-color if you ask me: a wall having its power and toughness determined by your land count strikes me as more of a Green ability, not Black. Ahh, the days before Color Pie....
184734: Drift of the Dead.text_posted:
@metalviolence:  During the initial Ice Age block you could run as many basic snow-covered lands as you wanted.  Since they did and still do qualify as basic lands there was no limit to the number of them you could have in one deck.  That's why this card saw some play, seeing as it could come out late-game as a large enough blocker to stop whatever beast your opponent was trying to do you in with.

Anyway, it's not bad exactly, but it's only useful in Snow decks and even then the cost is probably 1CMC too high. 184735: Balduvian Dead.author: longwinded
184735: Balduvian Dead.text_parsed: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper uses Graveborn tokens as a nod and a throwback to Balduvian Dead. Balduvian Dead used Graveborn because back then almost every creature had its own subtypes, and tokens were almost always weird, throwaway types. All tribal synergy was limited and carefully cultured, which is why, say Thrulls and Goblins got both tokens and cards in the earlier Fallen Empires set, but Thallid cards made saproling tokens, Homarids made Camarid tokens and so. Even the tribal lords weren't of the tribe (Goblin King was the ultra specific "summon Goblin King," which using the rules back then counted as neither as a goblin creature nor a king creature). I think we've seen exactly as much as we'll ever see of graveborn, unless someone decides to re-use the name on a zombie card.

Even the tribal lords weren't of the tribe (Goblin King was the ultra specific "summon Goblin King," which using the rules back then counted as neither as a goblin creature nor a king creature). 184739: Thunder Wall.author: thatmarkguy
184739: Thunder Wall.text_parsed: I liked this guy a lot back in the day. You rarely had to actually sink the blue mana into pumping it, because the fact that you *could* (blue mages always have blue mana sources untapped on the opponent's turn!) usually meant that you usually didn't get attacked at all. In fact, relative to the big 0/X walls, this cold-war mentality often held off multiple attackers. An opponent with 2 3/3s wouldn't attack with either of them for fear of you pumping up and killing one and keeping your wall, whereas if you had a low-power tough wall they'd keep attacking in groups to get one attacker through wile the blocked one lived on.
184739: Thunder Wall.text_posted: I liked this guy a lot back in the day.  You rarely had to actually sink the blue mana into pumping it, because the fact that you *could* (blue mages always have blue mana sources untapped on the opponent's turn!) usually meant that you usually didn't get attacked at all.  In fact, relative to the big 0/X walls, this cold-war mentality often held off multiple attackers.  An opponent with 2 3/3s wouldn't attack with either of them for fear of you pumping up and killing one and keeping your wall, whereas if you had a low-power tough wall they'd keep attacking in groups to get one attacker through wile the blocked one lived on.

184745: Songs of the Damned.author: Ferlord
184745: Songs of the Damned.text_parsed:
Can someone argue that this is better than Dark Ritual? Obviously you can. It just depends on the situation.

It's made specially for Reanimation decks... which made me wonder why the Graveborn deck didn't include multiples of this in it. Maybe a new art, eh? This one is kind of... difficult to understand.

Anyway, if you were to just play Buried Alive first, then it'd become equal. If you play another, of use Golgari Grave-Troll's dredge-effect or Entomb (you rich bastard), you can, at best, triple the ritual's effect.

It still isn't close enough to Dark Ritual, since you needed all those cards to be played before to get anywhere.

It's still one of my favourite 1-drops for black, though. They REALLY should have reprinted it for the Premium Deck, however.

184745: Songs of the Damned.author: cgermain
184745: Songs of the Damned.text_parsed:
A huge and fun play that happened in a game of EDH I was playing:

Had 9 lands open, don't exactly remember the division of lands, but there was at least three swamps and three mountains, and then I believe to be three non-basics. Tapped for seven, cast Morality Shift swapped my library and graveyard, putting about 30+ creatures into my 'yard. Played this, flashbacked Past in Flames, then flashbacked Zombify, targeting Balthor the Defiled, popped Balthor, brought back all of my creatured and stacked a ton of CitP/EtB effects. Then I flashbacked Morality Shift so I wouldn't deck myself.

This card is great late game in most creature-heavy decks

184745: Songs of the Damned.author: rzero
184745: Songs of the Damned.text_parsed:
This, plus Zombie Infestation, Sutured Ghoul, and Jace, Memory Adept.

Pop Jace''s ultimate to draw 20 cards, feed all the creatures you draw into the Zombie Infestation, then Songs of the Damned to play your Sutured Ghoul.

I was able to pull this off in a game, and the end result was a 25/22 Ghoul with five 2/2 Zombies. I've seen lots of ppl give Jace crap, but he's just unassuming enough that my opponent never bothered killing him when he had the chance.

184745: Songs of the Damned.author: blurrymadness
184745: Songs of the Damned.text_parsed:
Often when using this card it goes into a psuedo-dredge deck I run. Ideal scenario looks something like:

T1: Swamp, Putrid Imp
T2: Discard Stinkweed Imp during upkeep, dredge for 5

If you get 3-4 creatures you're already tying the best Rituals in the game. Now just cruise into the win condition of your choice (oh and feel free to discard that imp or any other creatures you might have now!)

This is a fun way to Living Death, ramp into a giant demon, or other neat ideas.

Honestly I'm not sure why there's not a super-dredge deck relying on this, exsanguinate or drain life, and loads of draw spells. I get that there is a lot of grave hate, but most of that isn't at instant speed, and if you run {G} you can probably nail the grave hate before it would effect you. Maybe someday this could be part of a Tendrils of Agony dredge hybrid combo deck in legacy?

Since it's a common, this could be an interesting idea in Pauper. Maybe add a Pit Keeper for good measure.

184749: Savannah.author: nemokara

184751: Tundra.author: DarthParallax
184751: Tundra.text_parsed:
Which is the most powerful Dual Land? Probably not this one.

To figure it out, first we ask- do I REALLY need the Beta Land, or is the Ravnica Cycle fine for my needs? The major difference is that Beta Lands are less vulnerable to the colors Red and Green in general, who seek to a do a big pile of damage A.S.A.P. which means you don't want to take 2 extra damage on top of the 1 for Fetching.

Blue/White- that's a color combination that knows how to be patient. And it plays SUPERB with Artifacts, which means you're probably packing Tinker and Sol Ring and something dumb and your 2 Moxen and Mana Crypt before you start thinking about which Lands you want to use.

Red/Green, or Red/Green/White- many of it's very best cards are made specifically better and aggressive by having the right land types out and the Duals can both count for these lands and tap to cast the creatures. I'm gonna have to say that Savannah, Taiga, and Plateau are better than Tundra, making Tundra probably the worst U/x Dual.

I might be wrong about this- I perceive that Tundra is not as necessary to a White-Blue mana base as the non-Blue duals are *necessary* to their mana bases because non-Blue doesn't play as well with artifacts.

Underground Sea and Bayou are so far ahead of the others it's retarded.

But it's all only a very few percentage points- each Dual has a printing threatening a 9.5 or higher rating on Gatherer.

184753: Angel of Light.author: DarthParallax
184753: Angel of Light.text_parsed:
This card's weakness foreshadowed the waning of Serra Angel. In my estimation, keyword abilities are usually worth more than +1/+1. If this, being more splashable than Serra, and thus fitting snugly in W/G, W/R, W/U, or W/x/y, to interact with all kinds of different creature improvements, was not good enough, it indicated that Flying and Vigilance alone were not good enough, but rather that Vigilance should be nearly as free as flying for Angels in order to be impressive.

Once you take away all the most powerful broken control spells, you can't win on a creature that only attacks and blocks- it needs more 'oomph' to make a real difference. 3/3 is very close to 4/4. I don't think 5/5 would be enough to make this creature a good rare, but it might make the cut as a finely playable uncommon.

184755: Musician.author: majinara
184755: Musician.text_parsed:
I think what's important to note is:
- the counters stay (including their "pay 1 or sac" effect) even once the musician is gone
- musician works well with cards like exhaust to prevent people from paying their stuff
- you can tap the musician in response to the cumulative upkeep ability. So even if you choose to not pay the upkeek a single time, you can use the tap ability

Still a bad card. But fun. :)

Unless you plan to use it so many times that the exiling becomes an issue (that is, at least six to seven times), yup, this card is much better and strictly better than Treasure Trove.

It's main usage is for combo, but it's bad for it because if you see two pieces of the combo you lose one. It's also 8 mana for the first activation, seeing play between T4 and T5; much later than combo enjoys.

That said, it searches deep and provides repeatable card advantage making it useful in EDH or Multiplayer. Mirror of fate can craft a perfect hand later as well.

184761: Browse.author: SilverstarWolf

The art gets the concept of the card across so much better than the name Browse does - it's that feeling of tearing through your library, throwing cards left and right to get to one you need. Also, a beast in EDH, where tutoring and filtering is that much more desirable and self-milling (usually) less of a drawback

184763: Pyrokinesis.author: DarthParallax
184763: Pyrokinesis.text_parsed:
there seems to be a great deal of disagreement on the 'Pitch' cards.

1. Force of WIll is the best. Im glad everyone agrees on that.
2. Foil is a bad Force of Will. Of course, freaking COUNTERSPELL, DAZE, and DISPEL are also bad Force of Wills, but STILL. It causes you to pitch 2 cards instead of one, meaning you better be countering something deadly, or your down c.a. using a Blue Counterspell for free. that's a bad place to be.
3. I looked up the rest of Force of Will's cycle today, and I would rank them as 2 ties, for 2nd and 3rd place. Contagion you can maindeck in a deck without Dark Ritual and risk pretending it doesn't have the free-spell rider. Maybe. But Pyrokinesis can kill more things if they're small, or one bigger thing than Contagion. That's why I give them the tie. Scars of the Veteran is a much needed decent rare port of Healing Salve- doing the same thing, only actually good enough to matter. Can save you from 2 or even 3 burn spells in a pinch. Bounty of the Beast sucks compared to the other options green has BUT it's probably better than most non-green creature-based spells. But it still is actually worse than Giant Growth, which for what was supposed to be a bomb rare is really sad.

4. BACK TO PYROKINESIS- 4x this and 4x Fireblast is the beginning of a very nice Suicide Red Deck Wins. 5/5 stars. (its hard to rate old cards properly. this IS worth 5 stars, other cards like Force of Will or Black Lotus are worth more like 7 or 8)

184763: Pyrokinesis.author: Bazzoka
184763: Pyrokinesis.text_parsed:
I personally find Contagion to be inferior to this. As a red player, I want creatures dead when I cast a spell, especially when I have to use two cards for it.

What Contagion can kill:
-two X/1s
-a X/2

What Pyrokinesis can kill:
-four X/1s
-two X/1s and a X/2
-two X/2s
-a X/1 and a X/3
-an X/4

If you ask me, the Pyrokinesis seems to do more for me than Contagion would. The only thing that's missing from this is being able to target players, but this card is already super versatile that if it had those two extra words it would make it a highly sought after card for all red players. Not to mention it would be another "4 damage for free" spell and Fireblast is already an amazing finisher for RDW.

184764: Viscerid Drone.author: majinara

According to the flavortext and mechanic, I assume that the Viscerid Drone uses some small critter (like a saproling) as a lure to get an enemy into a valley or something, and then drains a swamp to drown the victim. But since artifact creatures don't need to breathe, they are unharmed. Unless the Drone drained a snow-swamp. Then the ice and snow will seal the deal for artifact creatures too.

All in all a great card.

184769: Sea Drake.author: blurrymadness
184769: Sea Drake.text_parsed:
Why did he get nerfed via templating? If you unearthed him as written or you "put into play" somehow (not from your hand) then he wouldn't bounce the lands. This doesn't make him extraordinary, but still.

That said, since you target lands you can utilize fetch lands, dreamscape artist (later in the game), use him to get islands into your hand for discarding purposes, or various other uses.

Also, Zendikar lands like being bounced more. I see this working best in {U}{G} where you can get land advantage easily while avoiding the drawback. (Burgeoning is a great example)

184773: Mana Crypt.author: EvilCleavage
184773: Mana Crypt.text_parsed: I swear to you all I was freaking out, and I mean I was literally TRIPPING, when I pulled this card out of a Zendikar pack last week! I seriously felt that god had graced me, and SOMEHOW, JUST SOMEHOW, wherever they package or make MTG packs, that a Mana Crypt accidentally slipped into my pack :D. As if the machine that puts cards into the packs had a Mana Crypt stuck in it for fifteen years, and that it coincidentally slipped out and into a Zendikar pack that I happened to buy. I felt so extremely excited and ecstatic, I was overpowered by nostalgia and truly, it was, I believe to be the most magnificent moment in my history of playing Magic. Thank you so much Wizards! . . . I soon found out that they were doing this on purpose, and I have to say I applaud you guys out there at R&D or whoever decided to put these cards into the new packs. And as a bonus card, nonetheless! I was so excited to get this card because I started playing Magic when I was about eight years old, in 1995, and I had a lots of cards that accumulated over the years. I played until I was about fifteen years old, when I got a girlfriend, and was with her for a good four years. During that time my life was pretty much just HER, and unfortunately, she wasn't much into MTG. So I gave my little brother all my cards that I'd collected over the years and hoped he would gain interest. . . . . Oh I was FURIOUS, when I found out that he had traded all of them for a piece of junk, old, rusty, and seriously crummy skateboard. The kid screwed my brother and of course I was mad! Fast forward to today, I have been trying to reestablish my collection and I don't have very many classic cards. Pulling Mana Crypt was really a very special moment for me, and only boosted my love for Magic even more. Thank you Wizards, and long live MTG!

184774: Orc General.author: Palochka
184774: Orc General.text_parsed:
Braid_of_Fire's Card of the Day #1

This is the sort of card that makes the early expansions of Magic so incredible: it has provocative art, a build-around-me effect, and does something very flavorful and exciting. How does a white general inspire its troops? It provides a hero for them to all emulate, a lord which empowers them by his or her presence alone. How do Goblins and Orcs inspire their troops in red? They kill one, telling everyone else "this will be you if we lose". Red is all about emotion, and while that's difficult to capture in a card game, Orc General captures the sentiment that Orcs will fight harder with these emotions running through them.

In terms of playability, this card falls flat. It could absolutely squeeze its way into a non-serious Goblin deck if the tap effect was granted towards Orcs and Goblins or if the general himself was a Goblin, but the early Magic dichotomy between Orcs and Goblins, which are flavorfully almost the same, caused a terrible disconnect between the cards and made all of the Orc cards diminish in value over time as WotC replaced them with Goblins in every set. Considering Orcs would be more likely to have splashed into black in later sets, and Goblins were a little forced when they did such in Lorwyn, maybe this wasn't the best idea overall, but Goblins absolutely have their fanbase so I'll take it that their market research pulled for our goofy friends the Goblins every time.

184775: Personal Tutor.author: ChaosFire
184775: Personal Tutor.text_parsed:
Everyone complaining about this card not searching for instants, please listen.

Portal didn't have instants. Even the counterspell was a sorcery. It didn't mean "instant or sorcery," it meant sorcery. Wizards thought the target audience for Portal would be too confused by anything faster than sorcery speed.

That said, the only reason we even talk about this card is because Mystical Tutor got banned in Legacy. Yes, we all want it to be Mystical Tutor. But then it would be banned too, and combo decks would have been even more broken when they were legal.

As it is, the card works just fine in some combo decks, still being able to grab a Reanimate or Doomsday. Is it ideal? No. But it still works as the most effective non-Grim tutor for those decks, and when paired with the ability to draw cards, the "top of deck" clause doesn't even hurt that much.

184779: Nature's Blessing.author: jeff-heikkinen
184779: Nature's Blessing.text_parsed: I always thought this was a bit underrated, particularly as it was the first way I can think of to hand out +1/+1 counters to arbitrary creatures. (Unfortunately, at the time it was first printed, the rules cared where the counters came from, so this couldn't give a Trikellion extra pings, for example. This changed when Stronghold came out, almost two years later.) How often is giving a counter or a permanent keyword ability worth two mana and a card? Not often enough for cards like Lance to be playable, true, but I can think of much, much worse things to do with your extra lands late in a long Limited game.

184779: Nature's Blessing.author: N03y3D33R
184779: Nature's Blessing.text_parsed:
An old card that is deceptively powerful.
Banding is possibly the most complicated, but potent ability if used strategically.

Most banding cards are small, and fairly expensive white cards that take time to build into a reasonably sized force.
This card allows you to easily give banding and other abilities to modern, cost efficient creatures with less hassle. Banding lets you do insane things in combat that can easily turn fairly inefficient cards into powerhouses.

The best part about banding is that while banded creatures don't share thier abilities they do share the pool of toughness by which to distribute damage, so you can band a Deadly Recluse with a Saproling, block a Shivan Dragon with the spider, and have the dragon deal all its damage to the saproling while your spider deals the killing blow.
184779: Nature's Blessing.text_posted:

This card allows you to easily give banding and other abilities to modern, cost efficient creatures with less hassle. Banding lets you do insane things in combat that can easily turn fairly inefficient cards into powerhouses. 

The best part about banding is that while banded creatures don't share thier abilities they do share the pool of toughness by which to distribute damage, so you can band a Deadly Recluse with a Saproling, block a Shivan Dragon with the spider, and have the dragon deal all its damage to the saproling while your spider deals the killing blow.

184779: Nature's Blessing.author: Guest1162619373
184779: Nature's Blessing.text_parsed: @ N03y3D33R: Unless the saporling has flying or reach it cannot be assigned to block the Shivan Dragon, and you don't declare banding when you declare blockers as you do when you declare attackers, and you only need one of the creatures blocking that creature to have banding to gain the benefit of banding as opposed to attacking in which all but one of the creatures in the attacking group need to have banding in order to attack as a single entity/formation.
184779: Nature's Blessing.text_posted: @ N03y3D33R:  Unless the saporling has flying or reach it cannot be assigned to block the Shivan Dragon, and you don't declare banding when you declare blockers as you do when you declare attackers, and you only need one of the creatures blocking that creature to have banding to gain the benefit of banding as opposed to attacking in which all but one of the creatures in the attacking group need to have banding in order to attack as a single entity/[autocard]formation[/autocard].

184814: Snow-Covered Mountain.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
184814: Snow-Covered Mountain.text_parsed:
Doesn't Tarkir seem like a very cold place?

I'm writing this several months before Khans of Tarkir is fully spoiled. So far we know about Sarkhan Vol, warlords, extinct dragons, a large-small-large block structure with a unique twist...

And two extremely vague tidbits: there will be "something" returning to the game after a long absence, and "something" completely new, both things that many players have asked for. Could snow be the old thing? It would be extremely cool (huehuehuehue) if Khans of Tarkir reintroduced snow-covered lands.

I can't shake the feeling we'll be getting snow, but it's likely this will just be another dumb speculation that was way off! Either way, I'm sure it'll be another great set, I'm looking forward to it.
